Iron Deficiency (Anemia).advice: Low hemoglobin and RBC levels may indicate iron deficiency.
Iron Deficiency (Anemia).diet: Add spinach, legumes, eggs, fortified cereals to your diet.

Vitamin Deficiency.advice: Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency may be present.
Vitamin Deficiency.diet: Include dairy, eggs, leafy greens, and multivitamins.

Dengue (Suspected).advice: Low platelets and fever may suggest dengue.
Dengue (Suspected).diet: Stay hydrated. Include papaya leaf extract under guidance.

Viral Infection.advice: White blood cell profile suggests a viral infection.
Viral Infection.diet: Eat light, stay hydrated, rest well.

Typhoid (Possible).advice: WBC + neutrophil drop with fever may indicate typhoid.
Typhoid (Possible).diet: Eat soft, low-fiber foods. Avoid oily or spicy meals.

Malaria (Suspected).advice: Symptoms and low platelets may suggest malaria.

Severe Anemia.advice: Critically low hemoglobin suggests severe anemia.
Severe Anemia.diet: Urgent care needed. Iron supplements may be prescribed.

Pancytopenia (Critical).advice: Low counts in all 3 lines may indicate pancytopenia.

Thrombocytopenia (Severe).advice: Critically low platelets can cause bleeding risk.
Thrombocytopenia (Severe).diet: Avoid NSAIDs or blood thinners without doctor's advice.

Possible Liver/Kidney Issue.advice: Profile may hint at liver or kidney stress.

Possible Immunity Issue.advice: Low WBC lines may indicate immune suppression.

Bacterial Infection.advice: WBC spike with neutrophils points to infection.

Needs Medical Review.advice: Your report shows mixed or unclear patterns. A doctor should evaluate further.
Needs Medical Review.diet: Maintain a balanced diet and avoid stress.

Normal Report.advice: Your CBC appears within normal range.
Normal Report.diet: Continue a healthy lifestyle and routine checkups.

General Weakness / Nutrition.advice: Symptoms suggest general fatigue or mild nutritional imbalance.
